Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 26: Living in the wilderness
Then in the second week two gods from Brahma’s heaven arrived. One said,
Manual (བྲིས་ཡིག།) - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): སྐུའི་གཡས་གཡོན་གཉིས་ནས་ཚངས་རིས་ཀྱི་ལྷ་རེ་རེའི་བསྟོད་པ་བྱེད་པ་འབྲི། དེ་ནས་རྒྱལ་ཆེན་བཞིས་རྡོའི་ལྷུང་བཟེད་ཕུལ་བ་དང་། ཚོང་དཔོན་ག་གོན་དང་བཟང་པོ་ལ་ལྷས་ལུང་བསྟན་ནས་བསོད་སྙོམས་ཕུལ་ཞིང་། སངས་རྒྱས་ཀྱི་ཆོས་གསུང་པ་དང་། ཡང་བརྒྱ་བྱིན་གྱི་ཨ་རུ་ར་ཕུལ་བ་དང་། ཕྱོགས་གཅིག་ན་བདུད་ཀྱི་ཐལ་མོ་སྦྱར་བ་འབྲི། དེ་ནས་ཆུའི་ནང་ཀླུ་བཏང་བཟུང་གི་ཕོ་བྲང་དུ་བྱོན་ཞིང་། སྦྲུལ་གྱི་གདེང་ཀ་བྱས་པ་དང་། ཀླུ་དེ་རྣམས་ལ་ཆོས་གསུང་པ་དང་། ཡང་བྱང་ཆུབ་ཤིང་གི་རྩ་བར་རྩའི་གདན་ལ་མཉམ་བཞག་མཛད་པ་སྟེ། དེ་དག་ཀྱང་སྤྱི་དང་འདྲ། མངོན་པར་བྱང་ཆུབ་པའི་སྐོར་རོ། །
Manual - English: He is flanked by gods from the realm of Brahma (tshangs ris). Each of those gods praises the Buddha. The four guardian kings offer a stone bowl. As prophesied by gods, the merchants Trapuṣa (ga gon) and Bhallika (bzang po) offer alms. The Buddha teaches dharma to them. Indra (brgya byin) offers Arura to the Buddha while the demon joins his palms together on the side.The Buddha visits the palace of nāga Mucilinda (btang bzung) in the sea.  Under the hood of a snake, he teaches dharma to the nāgas. Then there is another scene of The Buddha sitting in equanimity on the grass mattress under the Bodhi Tree as in the mainstream.

Sun of Faith - English: "Captain, Conqueror, look upon the world, make it without sin. People will seek the precious dharma.  Please explain this supreme teaching."
The other praised him in the same way.
Then the Lord rose from his previous contemplative absorption.
He spoke about the bliss of peace. He experienced the joyful bliss of liberation physically,  and for two weeks he sat cross-legged without rising.
Then in the third week the merchants Trapusha and Bhalika arrived on the road from Vajrasana with about five hundred horse carts.
One of their friends had died and had been reborn, and he gave a prophecy to them and urged them, so the two merchants went before the Lord and offered him honey and sweet porridge.

Sun of Faith - English: The [Buddha] knew that the past Buddhas had accepted offerings in an offering bowl, and not in the hands or on a platter as the heretics did.
At this moment the four world protectors knew of this [event]. They each offered to the Teacher a stone bowl made by non-humans that was bright, pure, and without flaws.
Inscription - English: Four great kings offer begging bows
Manual - English: Then draw the four great kings offering a stone bowl,

Sun of Faith - English: Then, [the Buddha] knew that if he took [a bowl] from only one [World protector], the [other] three would be displeased. And if he took them from two, two would be displeased, and if from three, one would be unhappy. So he accepted from all four and he magically turned them into a single bowl.
Then in that bowl he accepted the offerings made by the merchants Trapusha and Bhallika.
Inscription - English: Merchant Trapuṣa and Balika offer honey and porridge
Manual - English: and the merchants Trapusha and Bhallika offering alms after the gods give a prophecy to them.

Sun of Faith - English: He gave them refuge. He taught them the dharma of rejoicing in giving.
Manual - English: [Draw] the Buddha's teaching of the dharma,

Sun of Faith - English: Then he went to the bank of the River Nairanjana, and he ate the food.
The honey porridge stirred up his inner winds and the Tathāgatha was slightly sickened. Wicked Mara came and prayed upon him to pass away.
“I will not pass away until the four communities are established, and until the path of pure conduct is taught to people,” said the Buddha. Mara was not happy, and he disappeared.
Then Indra took the great medicine Arura from the Jambu tree forest, and offered it to the Tathagata. As soon as he ate it, the illness cleared away, his stamina increased, and he recovered.
Manual - English: Indra's offering of arura [myrobalan] and, off to one side the Demon's folding of hands in prayer.

Sun of Faith - English: Then in the fourth week, a rain suddenly fell, and a storm arose.
[The Buddha] went to the place of the Serpent King Mucilinda. So that the wind and such would not harm his body, the serpents wrapped around the Lord’s body, and made a snake canopy.
Manual - English: Then [draw] [the Buddha] going to the palace of Naga Mucilinda, the serpents's making of the expanded snake head, and teaching the Dharma to the serpents, and again in contemplation on a grass seet at the foot of the Bodhi Tree. [Draw] these as is common. The section on the manifest enlightenment.

Sun of Faith - English: Then the storm abated. [The serpents] changed into the bodies of gods. They faithfully bowed and asked after his health. [The Buddha] taught them the dharma, beginning with the joys of solitude.
Inscription - English: [Buddha] teaches Dharma in realm of Serpent King Mucilinda.

Sun of Faith - English: Then in the fifth week [the Buddha] went to the Heart of the Enlightenment, according to his knowledge of the twelve-fold dependent arising, for a week he sat cross-legged. Then he arose from his contemplative absorption, and he uttered a pronouncement.

Then in the sixth week, [the Buddha] thought, “It will be difficult for others to understand this profound dharma that I have realized. Even if I were to teach it to others, because they have not realized it, it will only fatigue them. So I will live in solitude.”
And so he stayed, doing very little.
